records.content:
In this Activity, we assume that that, in 

Litchman et al. (2009)'s model of diatom populations in mixed layers:

The size-specific standing stock of diatoms is a proxy for primary production and availability to grazers and pathogens.

The mixed layer nutrient is a proxy for the intensity of competition among primary producers.
We use these proxies to address questions about the trophic impacts of diatoms in mixed layers.

hierarchy.lvl2: 1. Biovolume and nutrient concentration in monocultures
1. Biovolume and nutrient concentration in monocultures

records.content:
How do diatom size and mixed layer characteristics affect availability to grazers and pathogens?

Does primary production increase or decrease with different mixed layer characteristics?

Do mixed layer characteristics affect the intensity of competition by diatoms for limiting nutrients?### Procedure

Collect model results for a series of diatom sizes and mixed layer intervals, as shown in 

these instructions.

Assess whether:

Standing stocks of different sized diatoms in monoculture suggest differences in primary production and availability to grazers and pathogens.

Different sized diatoms are likely to have different effects on competing primary producers.

What are the strengths and limitations of this analysis?

hierarchy.lvl2: 2. Biovolume and nutrient concentration in diverse cultures
2. Biovolume and nutrient concentration in diverse cultures

records.content:
In diverse diatom populations, are the best competitors also the variants that maximize or minimize availability and competitive intensity?### Procedure

Collect model results for “all” diatom sizes in a series of mixed layer intervals, as shown in 

these instructions.

Assess whether :

In initially diverse diatom populations, “winning” variants have relatively large or small primary production and availability to grazers and pathogens.

In initially diverse diatom populations, “winning” variants have relatively large or small effects on competing primary producers.

What are the strengths and limitations of this analysis?
The following steps take you through Activity 1.

hierarchy.lvl2: 1. Biovolume and nutrient concentration in monocultures
1. Biovolume and nutrient concentration in monocultures

records.content:
In a spreadsheet, start two tables in which to record Biovolume (BV) and nutrient concentration (R):



Figure 1:Table for recording standing stocks and nutrient concentrations in diatom monocultures.

Data are collected in a nested loop:



Figure 2:Schematic of data collection for Part 1

For each mixing interval, T_{mix} = 8, 16, 32, 64:

For each cell size class, i = 0, 3, 7

Execute the simulation sequence:Start a population \rightarrow seed a monoculture \rightarrow run the simulation \rightarrow record the data

Make X-Y charts of your tables to visualize your results.

hierarchy.lvl2: 2. Biovolume and nutrient concentration in diverse cultures
2. Biovolume and nutrient concentration in diverse cultures

records.content:
In your spreadsheet, start a new table in which to record Biovolume (BV) and nutrient concentration (R):



Figure 3:Table for recording standing stocks and nutrient concentrations in diverse diatom communities.

Data are collected in a nested loop:

For each mixing interval, T_{mix} = 8, 16, 32, 64:

Execute the simulation sequence:Start a population \rightarrow seed “all” size classes \rightarrow run the simulation \rightarrow record the data



Figure 4:Schematic of data collection for Part 2

Make X-Y charts of your table to visualize your results.

hierarchy.lvl1: Activity 2: Competition and Evolutionarily Stable States
Activity 2: Competition and Evolutionarily Stable States

records.content:
In this Activity, we explore 

Litchman et al. (2009)'s hypothesis that allometries of storage and growth explain the larger size distributions of diatom populations in marine compared to freshwater mixed layers.

Litchman et al. supported their hypothesis by showing that their model resulted in 

Evolutionarily Stable States in which larger diatom variants were favored over smaller diatom variants.
Here, you will assess their conclusions using their model.

hierarchy.lvl1: Activity 2: Competition and Evolutionarily Stable States
hierarchy.lvl2: 1. Winners of competition in diverse diatom cultures

hierarchy.lvl1: Activity 2: Competition and Evolutionarily Stable States
hierarchy.lvl2: 1. Winners of competition in diverse diatom cultures

records.content:
What are the outcomes of competition among initially mixed populations of diatom variants?

Over which time periods do the outcomes of competition among initially mixed diatom populations approach their final state?### Procedure

Collect model results for a series of  mixed layer intervals, as shown in 

these instructions.

Assess:

Which diatom variants appear to “win” competitions for nutrients in mixed layers with different mixing intervals, starting from a diverse initial diatom population?

How long does it take for winning competitors to exclude weaker competitors?

What do your results suggest about how we should interpret the results of these simulations to predict diatom populations in real mixed layers?

What are the strengths and limitations of this analysis?

hierarchy.lvl1: Activity 2: Competition and Evolutionarily Stable States
hierarchy.lvl2: Part 2: Do “winners” of competitions also form ESS’s?

hierarchy.lvl1: Activity 2: Competition and Evolutionarily Stable States
hierarchy.lvl2: Part 2: Do “winners” of competitions also form ESS’s?

records.content:
ESS’s have advantages as summaries of evolutionary dynamics, because they are well-defined and often quick to calculate.
However, the requirement that the candidate variant be allowed to growth to steady state – thereby establishing the ambient nutrient concentration – means that

a variant can (in some models) be an ESS but not the dominant competitor in an initially mixed population; and

a variant can (in some models) be  the dominant competitor in an initially mixed population but not an ESS.

In diverse diatom populations, are the best competitors also the variants that maximize or minimize availability and competitive intensity?

Collect model results for “all” diatom sizes in a series of mixed layer intervals, as shown in 

these instructions.

Assess whether :

The dominant variant you found in Part 1 qualifies as an ESS, by excluding all other variants if it is initially established.

What are the strengths and limitations of ESS’s as predictors of diatom population dynamics in mixed layers?
The following steps take you through Activity 1.

hierarchy.lvl2: Parameters
Parameters

records.content: Set: n_{sizes}=16, z_m= 100, n_{pers}=128.

hierarchy.lvl2: 1. Winners of competition in diverse diatom cultures
1. Winners of competition in diverse diatom cultures

records.content:
In a spreadsheet, start a table in which to record the winners of competitions in mixed layers with different mixing intervals:



Figure 1:Table for recording dominant variants for different mixing intervals.

Data are collected in a nested loop:



Figure 2:Schematic of data collection for Part 1

For each mixing interval, T_{mix} = 1.5, 8, 18, 32:

Execute the simulation sequence:Start a population \rightarrow seed “all” size classes \rightarrow run the simulation \rightarrow record the winner
Important:

Make sure to run the simulation enough times to arrive at the true dominant variant – this can take multiple runs.

Record the winner by entering its size class under “i_win” and its size under “s_win”.

Make sure to record the approximate number of days the model took for a dominant strain to emerge.

hierarchy.lvl2: Part 2: Do “winners” of competitions also form ESS’s?
Part 2: Do “winners” of competitions also form ESS’s?

records.content:
Do a new series of runs, to fill out the table column labeled “ESS”.

Data are collected in a nested loop:



Figure 3:Schematic of data collection for Part 2

For each mixing interval, T_{mix} = 1.5, 8, 18, 32:

Execute the simulation sequence, in two phases:

Start a population \rightarrow seed the dominant size class, I_{win} \rightarrow run the simulation

Seed “all” size classes \rightarrow run the simulation \rightarrow assess if any variants grow

In the first phase, the candidate ESS variant establishes the nutrient environment.
In the second phase, other variants are tested to see whether they can grow in this nutrient environment.

Assess whether the “i_win” variant is an ESS, with a “y” or “n” in the ESS column.

If any variant is growing (that is, if it has more cells than you seeded) then “i_win” is not an ESS.

If no variant is growing then “i_win” is an ESS.
The DiatomSizeESS model outputs two tables of results, and two sets of plots, after each simulation run.

hierarchy.lvl2: Tabular results
Tabular results

records.content:
Tabular results are shown in the noteboook cell under the Run simulation button, and also saved in the text files 

standingstocks.txt and 

losses.txt.



Figure 1:Top: Table of standing stock statistics, averaged over the last mixing interval.
Bottom: Table of biovolume losses, averaged over the last mixing interval.

In these tables, the columns represent: i - size class, s - size, 10^s - cell volume, N - number of cells, Q/Q_{min} - fractional nutrient quota, BV - biovolume, M - “background” mortality, S - sinking mortality, L - mixing event mmortality

hierarchy.lvl2: Graphical results
Graphical results

records.content:
Two sets of graphical results are presented, each of which shows:- Top: fractional quotas (Q/Q_{min})- Middle: biovolume (BV)- Bottom: mixed layer nutrient concentration (R).



Figure 2:Left: Period-averaged results, over the simulation run.
Right: Plots  over the last mixing interval.

Period-averaged results, for all mixing intervals in the simulation.These plots show the long-term trends of diatom populations and nutrient.
“Period-averaged” means the variation between mixing events is averaged out, so that the long-term trends are easier to see.

Results during the last mixing interval.Variations during the last mixing interval.
These plots show the transient response to a mixing event, which removes a fraction of the population but also adds nutrient to support new growth.

Note that these files are over-written each time the simulation is run.
The following steps take you through a simulation of the DiatomSizeESS model on Binder:

hierarchy.lvl2: Setup
Setup

records.content:
Setting up the DiatomESS model on Binder requires two steps:

Open the Binder link to the model

Select Run all cells under the Run menu

If your screen gets confusing or crowded, you can start over by selecting Restart Kernel and Run All Cells under the Run menu.

hierarchy.lvl2: Starting a population simulation
Starting a population simulation

records.content:
Running simulations with a new population using the model requires three steps:

Select parameters under Setting up diatom variants and mixed layer characteristics, then click Set up population

Select parameters under Seeding the mixed layer with diatom variants, and click Seed cell population

Select parameters under Setting mixing event intervals, and running the simulation and click Run simulation

hierarchy.lvl2: Continuing a population simulation
Continuing a population simulation

records.content:
Continuing a simulation (without resetting the population) requires two steps:

[optionally] Add cells by selecting parameters under Seeding the mixed layer with diatom variants, and clicking Seed cell population

Select parameters under Setting mixing event intervals, and running the simulation and click Run simulation.

You can add cells, and/or continue the simulation, as many times as you want.
